newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Ridley to buy half of NZ salt group.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Ridley to buy half of NZ salt group.

text.p: Food group Ridley Corp Ltd said on Thursday it would buy 50 percent of New Zealand's Dominion Salt group from the Skellerup Group Ltd for NZ$36 million.
"The acquisition is being settled using debt funds with a down payment of just under NZ$6 million and a final payment of NZ$30 million due by year end," Ridley said.
"The investment is expected to have returns similar to those realised from Ridley's joint venture investments in Salpak Pty Ltd and Western Salt refinery," it said.
The acquisition involved the purchase of shares owned by Skellerup in three businesses, in which Skellerup was a joint venture partner with Cerebos Greggs Ltd, a subdidiary of Cerebos Pacific Ltd.
The businesses involved were Dominion Salt Ltd, Dominion Salt (NL) Ltd and Cerebos Skellerup Ltd.

"For Ridley the purchase creates a new business relationship in New Zealand between itself and the Cerebos group," Ridley said, adding the two companies had successfully operated the Salpak Australian joint venture for the past 34 years.

"The Dominion Salt business includes a salt field and refinery at Lake Grassmere near Blenheim in the South Island, a refinery at Mt Maunganui near Tauranga in the North Island as well as packaging, distribution and marketing operations," Ridley said.
Dominion had annual sales of about 120,000 tonnes of salt, producing half of that in New Zealand and importing the rest from Ridley's Cheetham Salt business in Australia.
Ridley chief executive Gary Busenshut said the acquisition represented a logical geographic expansion of Ridley's salt interests into an established market with similar to Australia.
"Dominion is a very sound business operating in a viable market which will deliver attractive returns," Busenshut said.
"Additionally, we believe there will be opportunities to explore operating synergies between Dominion and Cheetham in areas such as technology, processing, marketing and packaging," Busenshut said.
Ridley's share price was steady at A$1.60 at 3.50 pm (0550 GMT).
